text:
This article was originally published in The National

The past year has seen baking heat, water shortages, wildfires, flooding and storms, so what must be done to weather the effects of climate breakdown and bring a brighter, greener future for Scots and communities across the world?

It has been a turbulent year for the environment, from severe weather like never before, to rising misinformation over the climate crisis and political rollbacks on measures to cut greenhouse gas emissions.

Weather-wise, 2025 is expected to rank in the world’s top three warmest years since records began, with this summer the hottest ever known. It continues the trend where all of the hottest years in history have taken place in the past decade, with rising temperatures driven largely by use of fossil fuels.

This warming has brought everything from blizzards, tornadoes and floods to droughts, heatwaves, wildfires and tropical cyclones across the globe.

Scotland and the UK have not escaped the effects, with a long dry period sparking water shortages and resulting in the worst harvest some farmers have ever experienced. Numerous massive wildfires cause damage on an unprecedented scale, with outbreaks in Dava and Carrbridge the largest the country has ever seen.

Internationally, rapid melting of the Arctic ice cap continues – it is now the smallest ever recorded, with consequences for the rest of the planet.

However, despite the mounting ‘physical proof’ of climate change, misinformation has also increased, and political consensus on what to do about it has rarely seemed so fragmented.

The cost of living has continued to rise, with many more households pushed into fuel poverty due to rocketing energy bills – driven by volatile global oil and gas prices.

Meanwhile, Scotland’s workforce is suffering due to lack of support and planning to achieve a just transition for businesses and workers to move from dependency on fossil fuels to a low-carbon society.

North Sea workers are being axed in droves as oil and gas supplies continue to dwindle, with reports of 13,000 jobs linked to the petroleum sector lost in the past 12 months – including hundreds due to the closure of Scotland’s only refinery, at Grangemouth, and the Mossmorran petrochemical plant in Fife. At the same time there has been criticism that support for promised green jobs has failed to materialise, although Westminster has now pledged £120 million to rescue some operations at Grangemouth.

Green goals

Over the past year there have been several notable moments that will influence the direction of travel for emissions-reduction goals.

Environmental campaigners have welcomed progress towards phasing out fossil fuels, with the UK government’s recently announced ban on exploration and development of new oil and gas wells. Retention of the so-called windfall tax, a levy on profits generated though factors outside a business’s control – in this case high petroleum prices caused by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine – has also been commended.

Less well-received moves include the Scottish Government putting its long-awaited Heat in Buildings Bill formally on hold. And there has been criticism of a lack of forward travel on cutting emissions from transport, one of the biggest sources of pollution, with the goal to cut car use by 20% by 2030 dropped.

Worldwide, there have been some wins for the environment.

In July, a landmark ruling from the International Court of justice, the world’s highest court, found nations have obligations to act on climate change and cleared the way for legal action where they fail to do so.

Wind, solar and other renewable power generation overtook coal as the world’s leading source of electricity in the past 12 months, with major expansion in China responsible for much of the growth.

Looking ahead to 2026

So, as 2025 draws to a close, what action should be taken in the new year?

Members of Stop Climate Chaos Scotland (SCCS), a coalition of more than 70 groups from across all sectors of society, have come up with a list of five no-brainers that would drive forward climate action, provide jobs and help “transform the world into a cleaner, healthier and fairer place”.

1. The Scottish Government must produce a robust and effective Climate Change Plan to reap maximum benefits for people and the planet.

SCCS chair Dr Mike Robinson said: “In 2026 a new Climate Change Plan will be finalised – a huge opportunity to change life for the better for millions of Scots and help communities across the world at the same time.

“It must contain strong measures that create energy-efficient homes, better and cleaner transport systems and support for farmers to shift to nature-and-climate-friendly practices. These will also lower bills, safeguard livelihoods, improve public health and boost the economy.”

2. Scotland must support and drive community-owned renewable energy to bring maximum benefits and control to people living nearby.

“The move away from fossil fuels and to renewable energy is vital, but too many people across Scotland feel like the energy transition is being done ‘to them’ not ‘with them’,” said Liz Murray, policy manager for Community Energy Scotland.

“The renewables revolution is generating vast profits, but much of that is being extracted out of Scotland.

“Community-owned renewable energy brings income directly into local neighbourhoods. This income is then used for an array of things that benefit people living there, such as insulating homes, providing community transport, setting up local businesses and creating community gardens – and bringing jobs that go with those things.

“We need politicians to remove the obstacles and smooth the way to greater community ownership of Scotland’s vast renewable energy resources so that everyone can benefit.”

3. Plans to drill major new oil and gas wells in the North Sea must be permanently cancelled to avoid millions of tonnes of climate-warming emissions, and workers must get proper support to move into safe green jobs.

Rosie Hampton, oil and gas campaigns manager at Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: “Oil and gas are costing us the earth, from sky-high energy bills to mounting impacts of extreme weather from Arthur’s Seat to Indonesia.

“Our energy future must be built on renewables that are affordable and run in the public interest. Opening new fields like Rosebank would undermine the energy transition and divert time and resources away from creating decent green jobs with a long-term future.”

4. Scotland must introduce a tax on private jets.

Jamie Livingstone, head of Oxfam Scotland, said: “Private jets are one of the dirtiest forms of transport, yet thousands of private flights take off and land at Scottish airports every year, streaking our skies with a trail of pointless pollution while the rest of us bear the climate cost in floods, heatwaves and disrupted lives.

“Introducing a Scottish private jet tax in 2026 is a no-brainer: it could raise tens of millions for fair climate action, paid for by those doing the most damage.

“It’s time for the Scottish Government to end its holding pattern and make 2026 the year in which the ultra-wealthy’s free licence to pollute is finally revoked.”

5. Compensation must be secured for developing countries suffering the biggest impacts of climate change but have contributed least to warming.

Ben Wilson, director of public engagement for Scottish Catholic International Aid Fund and international policy lead for SCCS, said: “Climate justice funding is a no-brainer in 2026, especially as the Commonwealth Games comes to Glasgow.

“Commonwealth countries like Bangladesh, Malawi and Fiji, and many of the world’s other poorest nations, are already being devastated by the impacts of climate change. They didn’t cause this crisis. They didn’t economically benefit from this crisis. But they are suffering first and worst for it.

“Richer nations must stump up cash for their atmospheric vandalism to help communities on the climate frontlines.”

Action stations

Scots will be watching closely as political parties put together their manifestos for the Holyrood election in late spring, with action on poverty, energy and jobs expected to be among key concerns for voters.

One thing is certain, though, no matter the result of the election in May. With around a third of current parliamentarians stepping down, there will be a large cohort of new MSPs to engage with on climate issues.

SCCS is calling for strong national action on climate and nature.

Better protection for the communities most at risk from the impacts of climate breakdown is also necessary, to help safeguard people and livelihoods.

“There is more that unites us than divides us,” said Dr Robinson.

“We all want the same basic things – a world that is safe, healthy, bountiful and fair, with a bright future for generations to come.

“And all this is achievable with urgent, strong climate action.

“Surely that’s the best new year’s resolution anyone could have.”

title: why solar stocks are down today — explained - Bitget
description:
Why solar stocks are down today As investors and observers ask "why solar stocks are down today," the short answer is that a convergence of policy headlines, financing pressure, supply-demand dynamics and regional regulatory actions compressed near-term economics across developers, installers and manufacturers.
When investors ask why solar stocks are down today, remember that interest-rate sensitivity makes near-term revenue and margin expectations more fragile.
Monitoring these items helps explain any further episodes of volatility and why solar stocks could suffer additional downside.
For traders and investors attempting to answer why solar stocks are down today, these company-level fundamentals explain why certain names were hit harder than others on headline days.
Motley Fool, “Why First Solar Stock Dived by Almost 18% Today”, Jun 17, 2025; and “Why Are Solar Stocks Dropping So Fast?”, Jun 21, 2025.
text:
Why solar stocks are down today

As investors and observers ask "why solar stocks are down today," the short answer is that a convergence of policy headlines, financing pressure, supply-demand dynamics and regional regulatory actions compressed near-term economics across developers, installers and manufacturers. This article explains the proximate news triggers and the structural drivers, cites market moves and analyst responses, and outlines near-term catalysts to watch. It is factual and neutral in tone; it does not provide investment advice.

As of Jun 17, 2025, according to Reuters, a U.S. Senate draft proposing an accelerated phase-out of certain solar tax credits triggered a sharp selloff in many U.S.-listed solar names and ETFs. As of May 22–23, 2025, Yahoo Finance and other outlets reported House tax-and-spending language that also weighed on project economics. Later regional reports (including a Dec 8, 2025 note covered by Trade Brains) show how local regulatory rumors produced similar volatility in other markets such as India.

What you will learn: the immediate catalysts that moved markets, why policy timing and interest rates matter to solar projects, which segments are most exposed, and the realistic near-term scenarios that could stabilize or further pressure solar equities.

Immediate catalysts for recent declines

When people search for why solar stocks are down today, they are usually reacting to recent headline events that removed or reduced a key support for project returns: tax credits and other incentives. Two headline items dominated the moves in mid‑2025.

As of Jun 17, 2025, Reuters and BNNBloomberg reported that a Senate Finance Committee draft proposed phasing down components of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) clean-energy tax credits earlier than previously scheduled. Markets reacted sharply that day.

In May 2025 (May 22–23), coverage of House tax-and-spending bill language indicated more aggressive rollbacks or tighter eligibility rules that would reduce the value of investment/production tax incentives for new solar projects. That earlier coverage had already begun to reprice expectations for installation growth and developer revenue.

These legislative and committee-level items are immediate catalysts: the headline risk directly reduces the expected net present value of projects that rely on credits, which in turn compresses valuations for developers, installers, and — to a degree — some manufacturers reliant on near-term demand.

When traders and portfolio managers re-evaluated cash-flow models, many moved rapidly from higher multiple, policy‑sensitive names into cash or less-exposed sectors, producing the large intraday moves that drew attention.

Why headlines matter now

Solar project economics are often calculated with assumed tax-credit treatment, timelines to complete construction (to qualify), and expected electricity prices or offtake contracts. When a credible legislative draft shortens the timeline or shrinks credit rates, expected revenues drop and the value of projects under development falls — sometimes by a material percentage — prompting immediate stock revaluations.

U.S. legislative developments (House & Senate tax‑credit proposals)

A major reason investors are asking why solar stocks are down today is legislative risk in the U.S. that directly affects the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) tax credit structure.

As of May 22–23, 2025, multiple reports (Yahoo Finance and broader press coverage) described House-passed tax-and-spending bill language that rolled back certain clean-energy tax credits or tightened eligibility. That coverage put initial downward pressure on the sector.

As of Jun 17, 2025, Reuters and MarketWatch reported a Senate Finance Committee draft that proposed an accelerated phase-out of IRA solar tax credits through 2028. While some market participants judged the Senate draft less severe than the House language, the draft still materially reduced forward expectations for credit value and installation timing.

Why does this matter?

Reduced tax credits lower project returns: Many utility-scale and commercial projects are financed with models that assume IRA-level tax credits. Shrinking those incentives lowers IRR and may delay or cancel marginal projects.

Shortened construction windows compress demand timing: Developers rushed to secure tax equity and complete construction within earlier deadlines. A sudden policy change creates uncertainty about which pipeline projects will qualify.

Market pricing and capital allocation shift: Installers and developers with thin margins or heavy near-term project exposure (e.g., heavily levered residential installers or developers with backlogs concentrated near the eligibility cut-off) see equity valuations fall faster.

Market reaction to the drafts

On the headline days in mid‑June 2025, several large-cap solar-related stocks and solar ETFs dropped sharply. Reported moves included large intraday declines across both equipment makers and installers as investors re-assessed revenue visibility under a smaller incentive regime.

(See “Notable stock moves and ETFs” below for examples and percentages cited by contemporary coverage.)

Policy uncertainty and timeline risk for projects

Policy uncertainty is different from a definitive policy change. Even when a bill is not final, drafts or committee reports create timeline risk that affects financing and contract behavior.

Tax-equity and project finance require certainty: Lenders and tax-equity investors price in regulatory certainty. When the rules around eligibility, completion windows, or labor/content credits are uncertain, providers tighten terms or pause new commitments.

Developers face “hurry-up” or “wait” dilemmas: A shortened eligibility window creates an incentive to accelerate construction (raising costs) or to delay until rules are clarified (missing prior deadlines). Both outcomes are negative for predictability.

Pipeline reclassification: Some developers and public companies may reclassify or mark down backlog value if the probability that projects qualify for prior credit levels drops, producing negative revisions to revenue and earnings guidance.

This combination of timeline and eligibility uncertainty is one of the clearest explanations for why solar stocks are down today: future revenues that were previously considered baked into valuations are suddenly conditional.

Structural industry drivers

Beyond short-term headlines, structural factors have been pressuring margins and demand — amplifying equity sensitivity to policy news.

Financing costs and the interest-rate environment

Higher interest rates raise the cost of capital for long-dated projects. Key effects:

Utility-scale projects: Debt and tax-equity costs increase, lowering project IRRs and making some projects marginal or postponable.

Residential installations: Higher mortgage and consumer-lending rates reduce affordability for homeowners financing rooftop systems, slowing residential demand.

Discount-rate compression: A higher discount rate reduces the present value of long-term power-purchase agreements (PPA) cash flows.

When investors ask why solar stocks are down today, remember that interest-rate sensitivity makes near-term revenue and margin expectations more fragile. A sector already priced for aggressive incentive-driven growth is vulnerable to a higher‑rate regime.

Overcapacity, falling module prices and margins

Global polysilicon and module manufacturing capacity growth has reduced module prices and squeezed manufacturer gross margins. Effects include:

Inventory risk: Manufacturers and distributors holding unsold inventory face markdowns if demand softens.

Margin pressure: Lower module ASPs compress margins; for vertically integrated manufacturers the effect depends on cost structure and localized demand.

Price transmission: For developers and installers, falling module prices can be beneficial (lower procurement costs) but only if demand (installation growth) remains robust. When demand is expected to slow (because of policy or financing), lower prices do not offset the revenue impact for project developers and installers.

This supply-side dynamic increases the sector’s cyclicality and explains part of the sharp equity reactions when demand expectations are revised downward.

Regional supply-chain and trade measures

Trade restrictions, tariffs, anti-dumping duties, and localization incentives alter competitiveness across manufacturers. Examples of how trade dynamics matter:

Tariffs or import restrictions increase costs for buyers in markets reliant on foreign modules, increasing project economics uncertainty.

Onshoring incentives (investment or production credits) can help domestic manufacturers but often take time to implement and scale, creating interim uncertainty.

If policy-driven manufacturing shifts increase capital intensity or raise production costs, some manufacturers may see margins deteriorate in the near term even if the long-term demand outlook is positive.

These trade and supply-chain forces interact with tax-credit uncertainty and interest rates to produce outsized stock reactions.

Market segmentation: residential vs. utility vs. manufacturers/inverters

Solar is not a single business. Different segments react differently to the same headline:

Residential installers/financiers (e.g., public installers and consumer-focused companies): Highly sensitive to tax-credit changes, consumer finance costs, and local net‑metering rules. A roll-back or eligibility tightening often hits these names hardest.

Utility-scale developers: Sensitive to tax credit timelines, PPA markets, and access to tax equity. Developers with secured PPAs and completed financing have lower immediate exposure than early-stage pipeline.

Manufacturers and component suppliers (modules, inverters, trackers): Exposed to module price cycles, manufacturing cost curves, and trade policy; some may benefit from onshoring incentives while others suffer from lower ASPs.

This segmentation explains divergent stock performance: not all solar stocks move together, but many are correlated when the policy shock affects a large portion of the addressable market.

Market reaction and examples

When trying to understand why solar stocks are down today, examining the headline-day moves and which names were most affected helps illustrate the transmission mechanism from policy news to stock prices.

Notable stock moves and ETFs

As reported in mid-June 2025 coverage (Reuters, MarketWatch, Motley Fool), several high-profile solar-related equities and ETFs recorded steep declines on headline days. Representative examples from press coverage around Jun 17–21, 2025 include:

Enphase Energy: reported intraday declines in the mid-to-high‑20% range on a headline day (coverage cited ~27% moves on some sessions).

First Solar: dropped roughly 18% on June 17, 2025, per Motley Fool and other sources.

Sunrun: experienced very large intraday moves (greater than 40% on certain sessions reported in some outlets), reflecting its high policy exposure and leverage to residential incentives.

SolarEdge Technologies: recorded steep daily declines (coverage cited moves near ~39% on some headline sessions).

Solar-sector ETFs (e.g., mainstream solar ETFs tracked by market watchers and the MAC Solar Index): experienced broad outflows and NAV declines as constituents were repriced by headline risk.

Exact intraday percentages varied by source and session; the commonality was large magnitude moves concentrated on days with clear tax-credit or policy headlines.

Analyst responses and downgrades

After the headline drafts and committee reports, several sell‑side analysts and independent research shops issued updated notes. Common themes in analyst commentary included:

Revisions to project‑level economics: Analysts reduced near-term revenue and margin assumptions for developers and installers with large near-term pipelines.

Differentiation by business model: Some analysts emphasized that vertically integrated manufacturers with stable long-term contracts or lower-cost footprints could fare better than small-cap installers dependent on immediate tax credit timing.

Mixed severity views: Some analysts described the Senate draft as less damaging than the House language but still negative; others rebalanced coverage from growth assumptions to more conservative case scenarios.

These analyst notes reinforced the re-pricing and increased volatility as institutional holders adjusted models.

Regional variations and specific cases

The question why solar stocks are down today is often regionally nuanced: U.S. developments dominate headlines, but local policy and regulatory events in other markets (India, Europe, China) also produce targeted selloffs.

United States

The U.S. is the epicenter of the mid‑2025 selloff because IRA provisions had been a central driver of procurement and manufacturing investment. Key U.S. dynamics:

IRA rollback risk: Any credible phase-out or eligibility tightening reduces forward demand assumptions for both residential and large-scale projects.

Financing: The combination of policy uncertainty and higher rates tightened tax-equity markets and debt pricing.

State-level considerations: Net metering reforms and utility rate cases in key states (e.g., California) further complicate residential economics.

Companies with concentrated U.S. exposure and near-term project completion dependence were thus most affected.

India and other emerging markets

Regional regulatory rumors can cause sharp moves in local equities. For example:

As of Dec 8, 2025, Trade Brains reported that an MNRE (Ministry of New and Renewable Energy) rumor caused fall in some Indian solar names. Local clarifications or official guidance can reverse or deepen such moves quickly.

In emerging markets, domestic manufacturing incentives, local bank/ NBFC lending guidance, and import duties play a stronger role in near-term project economics than U.S. IRA-style credits.

Local regulatory uncertainty or sudden guidance changes therefore explain why some country-specific solar equities can drop even when U.S. headlines dominate global flows.

Europe and China-related dynamics

Europe’s demand and China-linked supply dynamics also matter:

Europe: Incentive programs, permitting timelines, and grid-connection bottlenecks influence deployment schedules. European installers and developers feel the effect when incentive expectations change.

China: As the world’s largest module producer, Chinese module pricing and export policy shifts affect global ASPs, inventory levels, and manufacturer margins. Sanctions or trade frictions (where applicable) alter competitive positioning and can amplify market moves.

Global investors often react to a combination of U.S. policy risk and China/Europe supply signals, magnifying sector volatility.

Short‑term outlook and potential catalysts for stabilization or further declines

When trying to answer why solar stocks are down today, investors should track a set of near-term catalysts that could reverse or deepen the slump.

Positive catalysts (could stabilize or lift stocks)

Clarifying legislation or amendments that preserve significant IRA-like credits, or that provide transition relief for projects near completion.

Central-bank dovishness or actual rate cuts that reduce financing costs for projects and consumer loans for residential systems.

Strong corporate or utility procurement announcements and PPA wins that validate demand for utility-scale projects despite policy noise.

Module price stabilization that reduces inventory markdown risk and supports manufacturer margins.

Local policy actions that strengthen domestic manufacturing incentives or provide tax-equity-like mechanisms.

Negative catalysts (could deepen declines)

Passage of legislation that materially phases out or tightens credits earlier than market expectations.

Further rate hikes that increase financing costs and further compress project economics.

Large cancellations of projects or visible tax-equity pullbacks leading to write-downs by developers.

Widespread inventory clearance at sharply reduced prices that signals prolonged demand weakness.

Monitoring these items helps explain any further episodes of volatility and why solar stocks could suffer additional downside.

Investor considerations and risk factors

This section focuses on neutral, factual considerations to understand exposure — not investment advice.

Differentiate by business model: Manufacturers, trackers, inverters, installers, and utility developers each face distinct risk sets (policy exposure, margin cycles, balance-sheet leverage).

Balance-sheet and liquidity: Firms with strong liquidity and low near-term refinancing needs are relatively better positioned to weather policy uncertainty.

Backlog quality: The proportion of revenues tied to fully permitted and financed projects versus early-stage pipeline matters for resilience.

Contract structure: Fixed-price EPC contracts, long-term PPAs, and manufacturing supply agreements change exposure to module-price moves and credit changes.

Macro sensitivity: High leverage, reliance on tax equity, or heavy consumer-financing exposure increases sensitivity to rate moves and policy risk.

For traders and investors attempting to answer why solar stocks are down today, these company-level fundamentals explain why certain names were hit harder than others on headline days.

Valuation and time horizons

Policy changes primarily alter near-term cash flows; many long-term investors view large-scale decarbonization as a multi-decade secular trend. The immediate re-pricing reflects near-term risk, while long-term demand assumptions depend on technology cost curves, electrification policy, and global decarbonization commitments.

Consequently, whether a recent pullback is a buying opportunity or a warning sign depends on horizon, exposure to near-term incentives, and company-specific execution and balance-sheet strength.

Historical context

Tax incentives, tariffs, and financing cycles have repeatedly driven solar industry boom-bust dynamics. Two historical points help contextualize current moves:

Past incentive shocks: When tax credits or feed-in tariffs were reduced in prior cycles, installations and public valuations corrected sharply — often followed by consolidation and eventual recovery as cost declines continued.

Technology and cost progress: Over the last decade, module-cost declines and efficiency gains have supported long-term demand even as cyclical corrections occur. The IRA (enacted earlier in the decade) had been a major growth accelerator; credible rollbacks therefore create outsized market reactions precisely because they remove an important growth driver.

Understanding that policy and rate cycles have historically produced large, often temporary, valuation moves explains why short-term selloffs can be severe even when long-term demand remains plausible.

References and further reading

Motley Fool, “Why First Solar Stock Dived by Almost 18% Today”, Jun 17, 2025; and “Why Are Solar Stocks Dropping So Fast?”, Jun 21, 2025.

text:
Will Lucid (LCID) Stock Ever Go Up?

Will Lucid stock ever go up is a common question from investors who followed Lucid Group's dramatic price swings since its public listing. This article focuses on Lucid Group (ticker: LCID on the Nasdaq) and synthesizes historical performance, the main drivers that move the stock, analyst views, recent catalysts, upside and downside scenarios, short‑term trading considerations, and a practical checklist for readers who want to judge progress. The intent is to present documented facts and commonly cited market considerations rather than to give investment advice.

Introduction

Many investors ask “will lucid stock ever go up” because Lucid surged to very high valuations after its SPAC listing and subsequently experienced a large drawdown amid production, margin and financing concerns. Public coverage shows mixed analyst views and repeated volatility tied to deliveries, guidance and partnership news. This article aggregates publicly reported information and common valuation drivers to help readers form an evidence‑based view.

Company overview

Lucid Group (originally Lucid Motors) is an electric vehicle company focused on luxury electric sedans and future SUVs. The company’s first production vehicle is the Lucid Air, a premium electric sedan notable for its range and technology; Lucid has also announced an upcoming Gravity SUV and has signaled plans for lower‑priced models over time. Lucid went public via a SPAC merger and trades under the ticker LCID on the Nasdaq. A sizable strategic investment from Saudi stakeholders and notable management hires have been part of its public story.

Historical stock performance

When people ask “will lucid stock ever go up,” they are often recalling the stock’s post‑SPAC trajectory: initial enthusiasm and very high valuations followed by a multiyear decline. After public listing, LCID’s market valuation soared into the tens of billions on growth expectations and EV hype; subsequent execution challenges, slower production ramps, and repeated capital raises contributed to a decline often cited as a fall of more than 80–90% from peak levels. Since then, LCID has experienced episodes of high volatility tied to quarterly delivery reports, guidance changes, strategic announcements, and macro risk events.

Primary drivers of Lucid’s stock price

Operational fundamentals

Operational metrics are core to whether investors answer “will lucid stock ever go up” positively. Key operational fundamentals include production volume, vehicle deliveries, manufacturing scale, and gross margins. Investors track:

Quarterly vehicle deliveries versus guidance and consensus expectations.

Factory utilization and ramp speed at Lucid’s Arizona manufacturing facility and any new plants.

Gross margin per vehicle and whether unit economics trend toward profitability.

Consistent, scalable production growth with improving gross margins is a primary pathway for LCID to regain investor confidence.

Financial position and capital markets

The company’s cash burn, debt profile, equity financing activity and remaining cash runway strongly affect market sentiment. When investors ask “will lucid stock ever go up,” they implicitly weigh the risk that continued losses will force dilutive financings. Frequent capital raises or high cash burn without a visible path to improving margins can keep downward pressure on the stock.

Product and technology factors

Product specifications and battery/pack technology are important. Lucid’s vehicle energy efficiency, range, charging speed, and battery cost influence both consumer demand and unit economics. The launch timing and pricing of the Gravity SUV and any planned lower‑priced models are material — successful execution could broaden addressable demand and improve scale; delays or disappointing specs/pricing can reverse sentiment.

Strategic partnerships and corporate developments

Large commercial partnerships, fleet deals and strategic investments move expectations about future revenue and distribution. Announcements tying Lucid to ride‑hailing fleets, delivery fleets or robotaxi pilots may create growth narratives. When such deals are reported, the market often re‑prices LCID based on the perceived size and profitability of those opportunities.

Market, policy and macro factors

Industry‑level factors influence whether people conclude “will lucid stock ever go up.” EV adoption trends, consumer incentives (such as EV tax credits), supply chain dynamics, commodity costs (notably battery materials), and interest rates all affect valuation. A supportive policy environment or improved macro liquidity can make capital‑intensive growth stories more attractive.

Competitive and execution risks

Competition from Tesla and legacy automakers, and execution risk in scaling manufacturing, are continual headwinds. Management turnover, missed timelines, or quality issues can exacerbate negative sentiment and increase the chance of further downward price moves.

Analyst views and published valuations

Analyst coverage of LCID shows a wide dispersion of opinion and price targets. Some outlets present bearish or neutral takes emphasizing capital needs and execution risk, while other analysts construct bullish scenarios based on optimistic volume ramps and margin improvements.

As of 2025-07-28, one prominent outlet published a cautious take emphasizing near‑term cash flow risk and potential for further dilution.

As of 2025-10-28, some market commentators presented multi‑year bullish scenarios that hinge on margins, Gravity execution, and meaningful fleet deals.

The divergence in published valuations typically stems from differing assumptions about long‑term growth rates, achievable gross margins, the cost and timing of capital raises, and the size/timing of fleet or partnership revenue. Because these inputs vary widely among analysts, price targets for LCID have historically spanned a large range.

Recent catalysts and news items that have moved the stock

Events that have historically triggered significant LCID price moves include:

Quarterly production and delivery reports that beat or miss guidance.

Guidance revisions for volumes, margins or capex.

Announcements of material partnerships (for example, fleet or autonomous vehicle pilots) and strategic investments.

Significant capital raises, insider or large institutional trades, or major changes to the board/executive team.

As of 2025-10-28, some published coverage highlighted how delivery beats or partnership news produced temporary rallies, while repeated capital raises tended to pressure the share price.

Upside scenarios (what would likely need to happen for the stock to meaningfully rise)

Bull case (execution + scale)

Lucid sustains a consistent production ramp and demonstrates increasing deliveries quarter after quarter.

Gross margins improve materially toward industry norms for profitable EV makers, driven by scale, cost reductions and optimized battery packs.

The Gravity SUV launches on time with strong demand, and any more affordable models expand the addressable market.

Meaningful, revenue‑generating partnerships or fleet contracts are converted from announcements to booked, recurring sales.

Lucid shows a clear path to reduced cash burn or positive free cash flow on a run‑rate basis.

Timing considerations

Such improvements typically play out over multiple quarters to several years; however, share price can react sooner to notable news items such as proof of volume milestones, margin inflection or definitive large commercial contracts.

Downside scenarios and persistent risks

Bear case

The company repeatedly misses production targets and fails to improve gross margins.

High cash losses force frequent dilutive financings, eroding shareholder value.

Demand weakens due to macro pressures or loss of incentives, or competition captures key segments.

Strategic partnerships fail to materialize into significant revenue.

Any of these outcomes could keep the share price depressed or drive it lower.

Technical/market trading considerations (short‑term factors)

Beyond fundamentals, LCID has demonstrated high volatility and can be influenced by:

Liquidity and daily trading volume.

Short interest and short‑covering dynamics.

Momentum flows, option‑related hedging, and headline‑driven retail interest.

These technical forces make short‑term price moves difficult to predict and can amplify both up and down swings.

How to evaluate whether Lucid stock "will go up" for you

If your objective is to evaluate whether “will lucid stock ever go up” applies to your portfolio, track a focused checklist of observable metrics and milestones:

Quarterly deliveries versus company guidance and consensus estimates.

Gross margin per vehicle and trends over successive quarters.

Cash runway and announced financing plans — whether dilution is likely in upcoming quarters.

Progress on Gravity launch timing, pricing, and reservation conversion (if reservation data is disclosed).

Evidence that fleet partnerships are generating orders or firm contracts rather than just letters of intent.

Management commentary and execution consistency, including manufacturing yields and quality metrics.

Analyst revisions and changes in institutional ownership.

Align any view with your personal risk tolerance and investment horizon. Growth, execution and financing risks mean realization of a positive scenario could take years and may involve substantial drawdowns along the way.

Reasoned outlook and balanced perspective

Under a credible path of execution, margin improvement and successful commercialization of partnerships, LCID’s stock could appreciate materially over time. However, substantial execution, financing and competitive risks make outcomes highly uncertain, and published price targets vary widely because they rest on divergent assumptions about production scale, margins and capital needs.

Frequently asked questions (FAQ)

Q: What are the fastest indicators of a turnaround?

A: Quick indicators include consecutive quarterly delivery beats, a sustained improvement in gross margin per vehicle, and signs that cash burn has meaningfully reduced or that the company has secured non‑dilutive financing or revenue‑bearing partnership contracts.

Q: How important are Uber/Nuro‑style deals?

A: Strategic partnerships can be important for growth narratives and distribution, but their value depends on whether deals are binding, generate near‑term revenue, and contribute to profitable unit economics. Announcements alone are less valuable than contracts and order flow that convert into recognizable revenue.

Q: How quickly could dilution happen?

A: Dilution pace depends on cash burn and access to capital markets. If operating losses continue at a high rate and the company lacks profitable free‑cash‑flow prospects, management may need to issue equity or raise debt within quarters rather than years. Watch reported cash runway and recent financing statements for timing clues.

Risks and disclaimers

This article is informational and not investment advice. Past performance is not indicative of future results. The information here synthesizes public reporting and common market considerations; it does not recommend buying or selling LCID or any other security. Investors should do their own research and consider consulting a licensed financial advisor.

References and further reading

The following public articles and reports were used to build this overview. Where a date is available from the source, it is noted.

Nasdaq / Motley Fool: Prediction: This Will Be Lucid Group's Stock Price in 2026 — As of 2025-10-28, coverage discussed multi‑year price scenarios. (source: Motley Fool via Nasdaq listing)

The Motley Fool: Prediction: This Will Be Lucid Group's Stock Price in 2026 — 2025-10-28.

The Motley Fool: Is Lucid Stock a Buy Now? — 2025-07-28.

MarketWatch: LCID Stock Price (company overview and quote page) — (MarketWatch company quote page; consult for market cap and daily volume updates).

Seeking Alpha: Lucid Motors: Dead Money In 2025 — (analysis piece referenced for bearish thesis).

Simply Wall St: Assessing valuation after Uber partnership — (coverage of valuation impacts following partnership reporting).

Simply Wall St: Can Lucid balance Uber ambitions with hurdles — (analysis of partnership balance and policy risk).

The Motley Fool: Could Buying Lucid Stock Today Set You Up for Life? — 2025-09-28.

The Motley Fool: Where Will Lucid Stock Be in 3 Years? — 2025-08-24.

Yahoo Finance: Buying Lucid Group Stock Today Could Set You Up for Life — (summary coverage referencing Motley Fool content).

As of the dates noted above, these sources provided a mix of bullish and bearish reporting and scenarios that inform the drivers summarized here.

Next steps and how Bitget can help

If you want to follow LCID more closely, consider these practical steps:

Track quarterly filings and delivery reports for production and margin metrics.

Monitor cash balance and financing announcements for dilution signals.

Watch for announced firm contracts or fleet orders rather than memoranda of understanding.

name: Clean Energy
title: The dark side of solar energy - Finshots
description:
In today’s Finshots, we take a look at some of the uncomfortable downsides of the renewable energy transition.
But its resurgence says something important about how the world is trying to fix its energy problem.
Solar energy sits in the same lineage, promising cleaner air, lower emissions, and energy independence.
For years, solar energy has been sold as the cleanest solution to our climate problem.
Replace coal plants with solar panels, add some batteries, and the energy problem largely takes care of itself.
text:
In today’s Finshots, we take a look at some of the uncomfortable downsides of the renewable energy transition.

But before that: How Strong Is Your Financial Plan?

You've likely ticked off mutual funds, savings, and maybe even a side hustle. But if Life Insurance isn't a part of it, your financial pyramid isn't as secure as you think.

Life insurance is the crucial base that holds all your wealth together. It ensures that your family stays financially protected when something unpredictable happens.

If you’re unsure where to begin, Ditto's IRDAI-Certified insurance advisors can help. Book a FREE 30-minute consultation and get honest, unbiased advice. No spam, no pressure.

Now onto today's story.

The Story

Over the last few weeks, silver prices have returned to the spotlight. There’s news about a supply crunch as industrial demand is climbing upward for the metal that usually lives in the shadow of gold.

At first glance, that seems odd. Silver isn’t oil. It isn’t coal. It isn’t even copper. But its resurgence says something important about how the world is trying to fix its energy problem.

Because every major energy transition in history has followed the same pattern. It solves the problem we are worried about at the moment, but creates a new set of problems that only become visible later.

Coal replaced wood and saved forests, but filled cities with smoke. Oil replaced coal and made transport affordable, but it made the world more dependent on fossil fuels. Natural gas cleaned up the air around cities, but didn’t really solve the climate problem. Each transition felt like progress, and each came with trade-offs that only became obvious at scale.

Solar energy sits in the same lineage, promising cleaner air, lower emissions, and energy independence. And in many ways, it delivers. But like every transition before it, there is a hidden downside that only becomes apparent at scale.

For years, solar energy has been sold as the cleanest solution to our climate problem. No smoke, no fuel, no moving parts. Just sunlight turning into electricity.

And to be fair, that story isn’t wrong. Once installed, a solar panel generates power with almost zero emissions. Costs have fallen sharply over the past decade, and installations are scaling rapidly. Governments, too, around the world are embracing solar because it seems to hit two birds with one stone. It helps meet climate targets and reduces dependence on imported fuels.

This is why solar is often framed as a silver bullet. The underlying narrative is simple and comforting. Replace coal plants with solar panels, add some batteries, and the energy problem largely takes care of itself.

These systems, though, don’t operate on narratives, but on physics, materials, and reliability. And that’s where the solar story starts to become more complicated.

Solar energy’s biggest limitation is also its most obvious one. The sun doesn’t follow demand.

Solar power generation peaks around midday, when the sun is at its brightest. But electricity demand usually peaks after sunset, when people return home, switch on lights, cook dinner, and run appliances. That mismatch creates a fundamental problem for power grids. The electricity is generated when it’s least needed and disappears when demand is at its highest.

To deal with this, grids need either extensive transmission infrastructure to move power from solar-surplus regions to solar-deficient ones or they need storage and backup generation. Either of these is expensive, stores power only for short durations, and degrades over time.

As a result, even countries with heavy solar adoption continue to rely on fossil fuels, hydroelectric power, or nuclear energy to maintain stability once the sun goes down or when weather conditions turn unfavourable.

So if we truly need a renewable energy source, it is something that must be predictable, scalable, and have low carbon emissions. Nuclear is arguably the only thing that ticks all three. But that’s a topic for another day.

Then, there’s another issue with solar that receives far less attention and yet looms just as large. And that is manufacturing the panels itself.

Solar power does not burn fuel, but it consumes an enormous amount of physical resources. Silicon is needed for the cells.

Aluminium for frames and mounting structures. Copper for wiring and inverters. Silver for electrical contacts. Glass made from high-purity sand to protect the cells. When you add all this up, solar ends up being far more material-intensive per unit of electricity capacity than coal or natural gas. Here’s an infographic to help you understand:

And mining those materials is neither clean nor low-carbon. From extraction to processing, the entire supply chain is highly energy-intensive. On top of that, components are transported across continents before a panel ever reaches a rooftop or a solar farm. Most of this activity still runs on fossil fuels. As a result, a significant portion of a solar panel’s lifetime emissions are front-loaded during mining and manufacturing. That said, we do agree that panels repay this carbon debt over time, but that repayment is gradual rather than instant.

Apart from this, as solar installations scale globally, demand for both silver and copper is increasing. Photovoltaic cells (the individual solar cell in a solar panel) manufacturing alone accounted for about 14% of global silver consumption in 2023, driven by its use in photovoltaic cells.

Copper demand is even more widespread, as we need it not just for solar panels but also for inverters, transmission lines, electric vehicles, charging infrastructure, and the necessary grid upgrades to support a renewable-heavy system.

Naturally, when demand grows faster than supply, prices increase. So part of the recent strength in silver and copper prices isn’t just driven by speculation or short-term cycles; it could also be because of this increased demand.

There is also a geographic imbalance embedded in this transition. The environmental damage caused by mining is local and immediate. Communities near mines deal with land degradation, water pollution, and waste. Meanwhile, the benefits of clean electricity are enjoyed far away, often in cities and industries thousands of kilometres from the point of extraction.

Once you add this to the cost of upgrading grids, recycling challenges for aging panels, and policy uncertainty into the equation, solar starts to look less black-and-white and more complex.

However, none of this makes solar a bad idea. Countries aren’t wrong to invest heavily in it. Solar is cheap, scalable, and far cleaner than the fossil fuels it replaces. It will almost certainly remain one of the pillars of the energy transition.

But it is clean only at the point of generation, not at the point of extraction. It reduces emissions gradually over time. And while it lowers fossil fuel consumption, it does not replace reliable, always-on power capacity one-for-one at an industrial level. Instead, it sits atop grids that still need storage, backup, and careful balancing to function smoothly.

The real risk isn’t overinvestment in solar. It’s underestimating everything else the transition demands. It’s that they might convince themselves that solar alone can do the heavy lifting, without fully grappling with the trade-offs, such as a poor electricity grid and subpar storage capacity, that come with it.

That said, apart from just investing in solar farms, countries should also allocate a portion of their budgets to these additional, but necessary, upgrades. Unless that gap is acknowledged, solar will remain both a solution and a source of new constraints.

Until then…

If this story helped you understand the nuances of the renewable energy transition, feel free to share this with your friends, family, or even strangers on WhatsApp, LinkedIn, and X.

Plus, we made sure to add our signature infographics too! Click here to access the PDF resource now.

And don’t forget to share this with your peers, friends, and anyone in your network who might benefit from it.

name: American Energy
title: 10 big energy stories Canary Media is tracking in 2026
description:
The tale of the clean energy transition is long and winding — and unfortunately, we here at Canary Media don’t have a crystal ball to tell you exactly what’s coming next.
Blue-state governors are backsliding on clean energy goals and easing up on fossil fuels under the cover of affordability.
Will politicians, companies, and others grow increasingly quiet on climate, all while the clean energy revolution speaks louder and louder?
— Dan McCarthy, senior editor The rise of virtual power plants What do you do when you can’t build actual power plants fast enough to keep the lights on and the air conditioners humming?
But it’s not all bad news in the Buckeye State, as some communities rally in support of clean energy.
text:
The tale of the clean energy transition is long and winding — and unfortunately, we here at Canary Media don’t have a crystal ball to tell you exactly what’s coming next.

But we can let you in on the big storylines our reporters and editors are keeping a close eye on as we head into 2026. Here’s the list, covering everything from companies on the cusp of tech breakthroughs to policy debates that are hitting a boiling point.

The decoupling of vibes from progress

Things are getting messy. President Donald Trump has gutted the only significant decarbonization law the U.S. ever managed to pass. Blue-state governors are backsliding on clean energy goals and easing up on fossil fuels under the cover of affordability. Oil and gas companies have dropped the pretense of caring about climate. ESG is dead. The ​“climate hawk” is dead. The words ​“pragmatism” and ​“realism” have become as inescapable in climate policy discourse as reminders of planetary warming are in the weather reports.

Yes, the climate conversation has changed dramatically over the last year, at least in the Western world. But the techno-economic trends that are driving decarbonization forward have not. Clean energy — mostly solar — is still being built at a blistering pace. EVs are beginning to run gas cars off the road. China’s emissions could be starting to decline. The world is on track for far less warming than it was when the Paris Agreement was signed a decade ago, and we’re still in the early innings of clean energy deployment.

In 2026, I’ll be watching this dissonance between decarbonization vibes and reality. Will politicians, companies, and others grow increasingly quiet on climate, all while the clean energy revolution speaks louder and louder? — Dan McCarthy, senior editor

The rise of virtual power plants

What do you do when you can’t build actual power plants fast enough to keep the lights on and the air conditioners humming? You turn to virtual power plants.

Utilities and regulators have in recent years begun to embrace these networks of rooftop solar panels, backup batteries, plugged-in electric vehicles, smart thermostats, remote-controllable water heaters, and other ​“distributed energy resources” in homes and businesses. By controlling this equipment to lower electricity demand and provide energy to the grid, utilities can replicate much of the value of a traditional, centralized power plant.

Now, the AI boom is forcing decision-makers to take VPPs even more seriously. Gigawatts of planned data centers are pushing up already high and rising utility bills. Equipment shortages are making it nearly impossible to quickly build gas plants, while interconnection bottlenecks are preventing lots of utility-scale renewables from coming online. And the risks of overbuilding to serve what could end up being an AI bubble are rising.

VPPs could help solve all those problems by enlisting energy tech that people are already buying. What I’m eyeing in 2026 is whether utilities, grid operators, and the state and federal regulators overseeing them put their weight behind the VPP build-out. — Jeff St. John, chief reporter and policy specialist

The make-or-break moment for the American nuclear renaissance

2026 is a threshold year for the American nuclear industry as it strives to lay the foundation for an unprecedented scale-up of atomic energy in the U.S. — quadrupling nuclear generating capacity by 2050, as per President Trump’s executive order.

The operators of the Palisades and Three Mile Island plants are pledging 2026 and 2027 restart dates for those mothballed reactors. Additional Trump executive orders are aiming for three advanced nuclear startups to achieve criticality in 2026. (One reactor has already staked that claim.)

Over the coming months, I’ll be tracking whether the industry keeps its bold promise of power-plant restarts and advanced reactor development. We’ll be reporting on the crop of nuclear startups and whether they can deliver on their audacious claims. And we’ll be watching whether the U.S. can start building nuclear reactors at scale.

If those plans are backed by sufficient capital and follow-through, they could restore some of the country’s lost atomic luster. If not, the U.S will have ceded its global nuclear leadership to China and Russia. — Eric Wesoff, executive director

The wind-energy win brewing in New England’s far north

Northernmost Maine has strong winds and lots of open space. But renewable energy developers have not yet managed to capitalize on these conditions to build substantial onshore wind farms, even though the idea has been floating around the state since at least 2008. Last year, Maine energy officials and regional grid operator ISO New England kick-started yet another effort to get turbines spinning up north with requests for proposals for both generation and transmission lines to carry the power south to the rest of the region.

I’ll be watching closely for a few reasons: First, the New England grid needs more power supply as the climate-conscious states it serves make moves to electrify buildings and transportation, and 1,200 megawatts of onshore wind would certainly help. Also, if the plan succeeds, it could offer valuable lessons about the economics of developing renewable energy in the face of federal hostility, which, I think we can all agree, is unlikely to abate anytime soon. — Sarah Shemkus, Northeast reporter

The financial case for electric buildings

As voters worry about the cost-of-living crisis, all-electric new buildings could help keep mortgage payments and energy bills down.

Though exact savings depend on local energy costs, a growing number of analyses have found that all-electric new construction makes financial sense. Building a home with only an electric system is often a simpler feat than building it with both electricity and gas. In some cases, all-electric homes can save people thousands of dollars over the lifetime of super-efficient electric appliances, such as heat pumps and heat-pump water heaters. Even retrofitting an existing structure with these technologies can pay off in the long term, especially in areas with favorable electricity rates.

Yet policymakers who once pushed ambitious electrification standards have been pulling back. Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass (D) waived her city’s requirement that new buildings be all-electric after last year’s catastrophic wildfires, then repealed it completely. In June, air-quality regulators in Southern California punted a plan that would have incentivized a gradual phasedown of gas furnaces and water heaters sold in the region. And New York Gov. Kathy Hochul (D) delayed her state’s first-in-the-nation all-electric building code, which would have taken effect on Dec. 31, 2025.

In 2026, I want to see if politicians and regulators will recognize that electrification can in fact boost affordability, especially in newly built homes. — Alison F. Takemura, staff writer

The geothermal breakthrough on the horizon

Geothermal energy startups have raised huge sums of money in recent months and years to develop next-generation technologies for harnessing Earth’s heat. But so far, the companies have delivered relatively little carbon-free electricity to the grid.

That will change this year, when Fervo Energy flips the switch on its Cape Station facility in Utah. The startup is building an ​“enhanced geothermal system” that uses fracking techniques to create geothermal reservoirs in hard, impermeable rocks. The first 100 megawatts (of an eventual 500 MW) are slated to go online in October, which would make Cape Station the biggest project of its kind to connect to the grid worldwide.

The development will send ​“a powerful signal that next-generation geothermal is moving from promise to commercial reality,” said Jeremy O’Brien of geoscience software company Seequent. ​“We expect this milestone to accelerate both investor interest and government support globally.”

Fervo isn’t alone in its ambitions. The company Eavor will start working this spring to expand its first-of-a-kind geothermal project in Germany, and firms like Sage Geosystems, Quaise, XGS, and Zanskar are accelerating efforts to satisfy demand for clean, around-the-clock power. I’ll be watching closely to see whether 2026 proves to be the pivotal year the industry is hoping for. — Maria Gallucci, senior reporter

The tug-of-war over clean energy in Ohio

Ohio, where I report from, has for years been a hotbed for dark money and a testing ground for national efforts to hinder action on climate change. State lawmakers and regulators continue to throw up obstacles to renewable energy development, while giving preference to new fossil-fueled power plants. One pending bill, for example, calls for energy permitting decisions to make sure facilities ​“employ affordable, reliable, and clean energy sources,” with ​“reliable” meaning energy that’s available at all times and ​“clean” defined to include natural gas. I’ll keep investigating those efforts in 2026 to hold the people in power accountable as the public struggles with rising energy costs and worsening climate change impacts.

But it’s not all bad news in the Buckeye State, as some communities rally in support of clean energy. One story I’m particularly excited to cover is a May referendum that will give voters the chance to overturn a local solar and wind ban covering most of their county — an approach that could take off elsewhere in Ohio and in other states that allow local restrictions on renewable power. — Kathiann M. Kowalski, contributing reporter based in Ohio

The AI boom’s battery awakening

2026 will be the year we start seeing batteries bridge the gap between data centers’ sky-high power demand and what the U.S. grid can actually deliver.

A well-placed battery system can secure electricity for AI computing hubs in the relatively few hours each year when the grid can’t supply them. That can allow data centers to get built far sooner than if they waited for pricey and time-consuming power network upgrades.

Storage developers are reporting a frenzy of interest in such projects, but these typically are shrouded in secrecy. I recently reported on the first publicly confirmed project of this kind, which entered construction in Oregon for Aligned Data Centers and should start operating in 2026. Utility Portland General Electric will own that one and use it to guarantee power a few years earlier than it could have with conventional grid upgrades.

What I found most intriguing is that the data center developer is paying for this smart grid upgrade. This arrangement lays out a rare positive vision for the nation’s energy future: The companies that stand to make boatloads of money on data centers could fund grid upgrades that benefit everyone, as opposed to the general public subsidizing those upgrades to pad the profits of AI ventures. In the year ahead, I’ll be tracking the proliferation of batteries for data centers, and what they mean for consumers’ energy bills. — Julian Spector, senior reporter

The fate of coal in the Midwest

Over the past decade, scores of Midwestern coal plants have closed, as environmental regulations kicked in and coal-fired generation became more expensive than natural gas or renewables.

Utilities are pushing back retirement dates for coal plants as electricity-demand forecasts increase exponentially due to proposed data centers — many of which may never get built. The Trump administration is ordering plants on the brink of closure to stay open and easing up on rules around pollution from coal power. Indiana’s Republican Gov. Mike Braun issued an executive order last spring calling for coal plant ​“life extensions,” and Illinois experts are researching controversial ​“clean coal technologies,” including at a demonstration carbon-capture plant that went online in 2024.

Coal is embedded in the culture in these states, and it’s highly political, as I’ve heard many times from elected officials, grassroots activists, and coal miners. In 2026, I’ll be closely tracking how this campaign to revive coal progresses and what it means on the ground in Midwest communities where it is burned and mined. After all, coal isn’t just an increasingly expensive way to generate electricity; it’s also incredibly polluting. — Kari Lydersen, contributing reporter based in Illinois

Thanks to President Trump’s ire, it’s likely that no new offshore wind farms will be completed in the U.S. until 2035, save for the five projects already being built, BloombergNEF predicted in early December. Even those projects aren’t guaranteed, a fact underscored by the 90-day pause on wind farm construction issued Dec. 22 by the Interior Department.

But Northeast U.S. states aren’t giving up on the renewable energy source. Massachusetts is exploring sourcing offshore wind power from Canada, with Democratic Gov. Maura Healey meeting with Nova Scotia’s premier last month to discuss partnering on energy needs. Maine also seems interested.

In 2026, I’ll be keeping a close eye on whether these deals materialize — and what they mean for North America’s offshore wind workforce and supply chain, which grew under the Biden administration and could otherwise wither away under Trump 2.0. — Clare Fieseler, reporter

January 05, 2026 Will the recently notified ‘Renewable Energy and Related Matters, 2025’ regulation be adequate to upscale rooftop solar in the state?
The state of Kerala has been an early adopter of Rooftop solar systems in the country with a current installed capacity over 1.5GW.
Recently, the Kerala State Electricity Commission (KSERC) released regulations on Renewable Energy and related matters (draft) 2025 with deep impact on implementation of the rooftop solar systems in the state.
The discussion paper explores how the current rules can raise higher costs for the users and slow the pace of adoption.

January 05, 2026

Will the recently notified ‘Renewable Energy and Related Matters, 2025’ regulation be adequate to upscale rooftop solar in the state?

The state of Kerala has been an early adopter of Rooftop solar systems in the country with a current installed capacity over 1.5GW. Prevalence of various flagship initiatives have led to the surge in capacity. Recently, the Kerala State Electricity Commission (KSERC) released regulations on Renewable Energy and related matters (draft) 2025 with deep impact on implementation of the rooftop solar systems in the state. The discussion paper explores how the current rules can raise higher costs for the users and slow the pace of adoption. The paper argues for various agendas towards an inclusive policy making dialogue with focus on improving integrated storage mechanisms alongside developing a dialogue for reforming the metering arrangements in rooftop systems.

title: Consumers and OG&E clash over new Oklahoma utility rate law | The Journal Record
description:
In a fiery statement released in December, the Oklahoma Industrial Energy Consumers (OIEC) and AARP Oklahoma called for Oklahoma Corporation Commissioners to reject a rate hike request for two new power plants planned for completion east of Oklahoma City in 2029.
“If there is a Scrooge this holiday season it is OG&E,” said AARP Oklahoma State Director Sean Voskuhl.
“On the heels of OG&E’s $500 million pre-approval case, where the Oklahoma Corporation Commission rejected OG&E’s attempt to recover an additional $100 million in financing costs, they turned right around and are asking for it again,” Voskuhl said.
The law allows utilities to ask for rate increases to help pay for Construction Work In Progress, otherwise known as CWIP.
OG&E believes the law requires the use of CWIP, while consumer advocates disagree, calling the law unconstitutional.
text:
Consumer advocacy groups are lining up against an OG&E rate increase request, marking what could become a major test of a new law that changes the way utilities can pay for new construction.

In a fiery statement released in December, the Oklahoma Industrial Energy Consumers (OIEC) and AARP Oklahoma called for Oklahoma Corporation Commissioners to reject a rate hike request for two new power plants planned for completion east of Oklahoma City in 2029.

“If there is a Scrooge this holiday season it is OG&E,” said AARP Oklahoma State Director Sean Voskuhl.

“On the heels of OG&E’s $500 million pre-approval case, where the Oklahoma Corporation Commission rejected OG&E’s attempt to recover an additional $100 million in financing costs, they turned right around and are asking for it again,” Voskuhl said. “OG&E simply cannot take ‘No’ for an answer, but they should.”

The opposing sides are arguing over new regulatory parameters created by Oklahoma Senate Bill 998, which passed during the last legislative session. The law allows utilities to ask for rate increases to help pay for Construction Work In Progress, otherwise known as CWIP.

OG&E believes the law requires the use of CWIP, while consumer advocates disagree, calling the law unconstitutional.

Under CWIP, commissioners can approve rate increases to pay for projects as they are being built. Prior to the law, utilities were required to wait until facilities were completed and operational before they could ask to raise rates.

OG&E says a rate increase through the new law would allow it to raise construction funding while the project is underway, which would help reduce the amount of interest accrued on $506 million in construction loan debt. The company estimates it could save as much as $173 million in interest costs, which is an expense that would be passed on to ratepayers.

The new law provides an avenue for saving ratepayers money, said Christi Woodworth, OG&E vice president of marketing and communications.

“Historically, we’d go borrow the money to build facilities. Then, when they’re operational and turned on, we’d start putting it into rates,” she said. “Meanwhile, we’re making interest payments all along the way, but customers aren’t helping provide the dollars for that until the project is fully operational, which means all of that interest accumulates.”

Adam Singer, attorney for AARP Oklahoma said that’s not the case. “Basically, they’re asking some, or many of their customers to pay for facilities that they may never see the benefit of.”

“You may have people that move away, start paying today and move away after two years, so now they’ve paid for a facility they don’t get the benefit of. Or, you have an elderly person who passes away, and even though they’re near the end of their life, their rates have gone up.

“There’s a reason in my eyes that the company is pushing so hard for these changes, and I think it’s just dollars,” Singer said. “I think Senate Bill 998 is unconstitutional.”

OIEC Executive Director Thomas Schroedter says the new law and OG&E’s rate request will end up costing ratepayers more than the traditional way of financing construction, and he believes the legislature made a mistake in passing the measure.

“It’s not in the best interest of ratepayers if you take the time value of money into account,” said Schroedter, whose organization represents about 30 member companies that consume large amounts of electricity. “The law interferes with the Corporation Commission’s authority to ensure just and reasonable rates for utility customers.”

Every one of OG&E’s stakeholders and PSO stakeholders oppose the law, Shroedter said, “and so in this upcoming session, the legislature needs to repeal this ill-conceived law.”

The law will subsidize a budding data center industry, which is rapidly expanding with new development across the state, he said.

“What’s happening here is OG&E customers are being forced to finance these power plants for these new large-load customers, and it’s not right,” Schroedter said. “If it’s upheld, the new law will require customers to finance capital investments needed to serve large-load artificial intelligence customers that will be coming on to OG&E’s system in the future.

“The data centers won’t be built for eight years from now and they won’t be paying any of the financing costs of these plants, so current ratepayers will be subsidizing these plants,” he said. “That’s unfair.”

The new rate case will mark the second time OG&E has asked for advanced funding for its planned plants at Horseshoe Lake. The Corporation Commission turned the utility’s request down in early December.

Schroedter says commissioners denied the company’s request once and OG&E shouldn’t be allowed to have another bite at the apple.

But the power company contends that its first request was turned down for legal reasons. Its initial request was submitted to the commission in May, which was three months before the new law went into effect.

Now that the law is in effect, OG&E says the Oklahoma Legislature now requires the use of CWIP because it significantly reduces overall interest costs incurred during construction.
